instruction: What is the purpose of the modular processing chain described in the related study for deriving global high-resolution maps of leaf traits?
Output: The purpose of the modular processing chain described in the related study is to derive global high-resolution maps of leaf traits. This chain utilizes machine learning techniques, optical remote sensing data (MODIS/Landsat), and climate data to fill gaps in the leaf trait database, maximize the representativeness of the dataset, aggregate plant species to Plant Functional Types (PFTs), calculate the spatial abundance of PFTs, and predict trait estimates globally using remote sensing and climate data. The chain aims to provide accurate and comprehensive global maps of specific leaf area, leaf dry matter content, leaf nitrogen and phosphorus content per dry mass, and leaf nitrogen/phosphorus ratio, along with associated uncertainty estimates.

instruction: Can the modular processing chain described in the paper be used to derive global high-resolution maps of leaf traits using spectroscopic methods instead of machine learning techniques?
Output: No, the modular processing chain described in the paper cannot be used to derive global high-resolution maps of leaf traits using spectroscopic methods instead of machine learning techniques. The paper specifically mentions that the processing chain exploits machine learning techniques along with optical remote sensing data (MODIS/Landsat) and climate data for gap filling and up-scaling of in-situ measured leaf traits. Spectroscopic methods are not mentioned as part of the processing chain.
